Award.AwardTitle: Symmetric functions in Combinatorics and Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will address important problems in combinatorics and representation theory using new tools in symmetric function theory. The proposed program will develop the theory of dual equivalence graphs, a powerful, combinatorial tool for establishing the Schur positivity of quasisymmetric functions, and provide new applications to important classes of functions. The program will deepen the connection between dual equivalence graphs and crystal graphs while generalizing dual equivalence graphs to other classical
types, thereby expanding the applicability of the dual equivalence graph machinery to representation theory of classical groups. The program will also introduce a new family of symmetric functions that will provide a combinatorial understanding of the stable Kronecker coefficients, which, in turn, should lead to a better understanding of the Kronecker coefficients.

Symmetric function theory plays an important role in many areas of mathematics including algebraic combinatorics, representation theory, Lie groups and Lie algebras, algebraic geometry and the theory of special functions. Results in this area have applications to many other areas of mathematics as well as to physics and computer science. In addition to solving important, long-standing problems in symmetric functions, the proposed program will develop versatile new tools with which to tackle fundamental open problems and deepen our understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the funded proposal, the PI set out to develop powerful extensions of a new framework for proving combinatorial results about representation theoretic objects. The main outputs of this effort are threefold.

First, the PI refined and extented the theory of dual equivalence and its application to an important class of functions. Dual equivalence gives a universal method to prove results that previously were addressed using ad hoc techniques on a case by case basis. The first of three foundational papers was published under this grant, and the second has been submitted.

Second, the PI generalized dual equivalence from type A to type B. The solution to this problem was optimal, in that the type B versions retains the full power and generality of the original type A method. In addition, this method allowed the PI to give suprisingly short proofs of two deep results in the theory of Schur P-functions. This project has also blossomed into a fruitful research project for one of the PI's graduate students.

Third, with David Speyer and others, the PI made significant advances in the understanding of Kronecker coefficients. Speyer and the PI discovered that their work on stable Kronecker coefficients also led the way to a new combinatorial understanding of certain plethysms. Inspired by the project, the PI collaborated with several researchers at an AIM workshop to give a complete characterization of multiplicity-free Kronecker products. These advances are significant contributions to a difficult area of mathematics.

The PI used funding to speak at several research conferences. In addition to presenting her work, these conferences afforded the PI opportunity to begin exciting new collaborations on related projects. Funding for the PI's graduate student allowed her to attend a conference and work on research over the summer where she made great progress toward her thesis.
